s.text: As early as 1977, when the stock market wallowed in the doldrums, Wall Street chronicler Robert Sobel observed that a successful analyst could "become something of a celebrity, called by New York Times and Wall Street Journal reporters ...

As early as 1977, when the stock market wallowed in the doldrums, Wall Street chronicler Robert Sobel observed that a successful analyst could "become something of a celebrity, called by New York Times and Wall Street Journal reporters ...

As early as 1977, when the stock market wallowed in the doldrums, Wall Street chronicler Robert Sobel observed that a successful analyst could "become something of a celebrity, called by New York Times and Wall Street Journal reporters ...
In the short term , however, the effect has been to increase price volatility, especially when analysts issue "strong buy" or "sell" recommendations.
I think "buy" still means "buy," but then some houses use "strong buy," so who knows?
We are, of course, in a bull market, which means that analysts should have been recommending that clients buy more often than they sell.
Their issuing of "short-term buy" or "short-term hold" recommendations obviously intensifies pressure on companies to meet and beat earnings expectations at all costs.

By 1984, when the bull market was just beginning, analysts were being called "minigods"; and by the late 1980s, top analysts were pulling down salaries in the high six figures, although they were still a long way from the Masters of the Universe terrain then reserved for bond traders and deal makers.
Kurlak is simply an extreme example of Wall Street's new reality, which is that no one has as much influence as the people who supposedly know where a company's stock price is going to go.
Kurlak is simply an extreme example of Wall Street's new reality, which is that no one has as much influence as the people who supposedly know where a company's stock price is going to go.
Kurlak is simply an extreme example of Wall Street's new reality, which is that no one has as much influence as the people who supposedly know where a company's stock price is going to go.

Even as analysts have become more able to move stock prices, their more corporate-congenial language has probably diminished the long-range impact of their recommendations--with so many "outperforms" and "accumulates" out there, it's hard to know which ones to take seriously.

Even as analysts have become more able to move stock prices, their more corporate-congenial language has probably diminished the long-range impact of their recommendations--with so many "outperforms" and "accumulates" out there, it's hard to know which ones to take seriously.
